description: Borrowed from Latin distractus, from distrahō (“to pull apart”), from dis- + trahō (“to pull”).

examples: (Alone shee beeing left the spoyle of love and death,
In labour of her griefe outrageously distract,
The utmost of her spleene on her false lord to act)

verbs.description: distract (third-person singular simple present distracts, present participle distracting, simple past and past participle distracted)

examples: The crowd was distracted by a helicopter hovering over the stadium when the only goal of the game was scored.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make crazy or insane; to drive to distraction.
